description: As one of the cornerstones of the Office suite, Word is a powerful word processor that allows users to create both simple and sophisticated documents. This series explores the essentials to getting started with Word 2016 on a Windows operating system.  We begin with basic skills such as navigating a document, selecting text, inputting basic text, and document proofing.  The series also explores all aspects of character and paragraph formatting as well as page formatting and layout.  While this series is designed for beginner users, it has lots of great tips and tricks experienced users as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate the different document views and zoom options available in Word 2016 for Mac. Here you will see how to work with the read mode, web layout, outline, draft, and print layout views. They also cover single and multi-page view, the ruler, and zoom functions.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how to input text and explain special characters in Word 2016. They talk about adding basic text like letters, numbers, and symbols like \*/%/@. They also explain the difference between backspace and delete, paragraphs and line-breaks, and tabs. Finally, they explain the show non-printing characters button’s function and dive into some history about different character sets.

>> Okay, because I always
have my show hide characters.

554
00:28:26.340 --> 00:28:31.150
I work in a Macintosh and
a PC environment.

555
00:28:31.150 --> 00:28:34.180
I work with lots of files from
lots of different peoples.

556
00:28:34.180 --> 00:28:38.880
I see this all the time,
especially in tables, and

557
00:28:38.880 --> 00:28:41.860
where they've copied it from some website.

558
00:28:41.860 --> 00:28:46.507
It's usually from websites, because
a lot of times when you're talking about

559
00:28:46.507 --> 00:28:49.428
coding for web pages,
you can only hit one space.

560
00:28:49.428 --> 00:28:51.948
It will only render, but let me back up.

561
00:28:51.948 --> 00:28:53.604
You can hit the space bar
as many times as you want.

562
00:28:53.604 --> 00:28:57.857
But in HTML coding, it will only render
on the screen as one single space,

563
00:28:57.857 --> 00:29:00.930
even if you have 15 of them in your code.

564
00:29:00.930 --> 00:29:04.640
But to force the space over, talking
about these non-printing characters,

565
00:29:04.640 --> 00:29:07.237
you have to do what's known
as a non-printing space.

566
00:29:07.237 --> 00:29:12.940
A non-breaking space is
Shift+ Ctrl+Space bar, and you see this.

567
00:29:12.940 --> 00:29:17.380
So I've gotten documents from people,
especially since I do a lot of designing,

568
00:29:17.380 --> 00:29:18.790
like, here, here's all our information.

569
00:29:18.790 --> 00:29:20.691
Now make it pretty into a nice flier or
whatever.

570
00:29:20.691 --> 00:29:24.988
I go ahead and get the text, and
I see all of this cuz they've copied it.

571
00:29:24.988 --> 00:29:27.272
And so I have to come in here and
say, nope,

572
00:29:27.272 --> 00:29:29.435
get the non-breaking spaces out of it.

573
00:29:29.435 --> 00:29:34.681
I don't want that, because it's not going
to render, or do what I want it to do.

574
00:29:34.681 --> 00:29:37.060
So I have to pull it all out.

575
00:29:37.060 --> 00:29:41.700
But if I didn't know that there was a
button in Word that would even allow me to

576
00:29:41.700 --> 00:29:45.750
see that, you're like,
it just will not stop moving over.

577
00:29:45.750 --> 00:29:47.390
Why does it keep moving over?

578
00:29:47.390 --> 00:29:49.240
You probably have those in there.

579
00:29:49.240 --> 00:29:52.240
Or you might have a line break,
or a tab, or a section,

580
00:29:52.240 --> 00:29:53.830
or all those different things.

581
00:29:53.830 --> 00:29:56.420
It is like,
to me it's like the Holy Grail.

582
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:56.970
>> Yeah.

583
00:29:56.970 --> 00:29:57.994
>> Why is Word doing this?

584
00:29:57.994 --> 00:29:59.060
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

585
00:29:59.060 --> 00:29:59.968
>> That's why.

586
00:29:59.968 --> 00:30:04.594
There's a whole world of special
characters and non-printing characters

587
00:30:04.594 --> 00:30:09.506
that is telling your document what to do
all based on our ASCII, and our Unicode,

588
00:30:09.506 --> 00:30:12.280
and so, keep that button in your mind.

589
00:30:12.280 --> 00:30:13.490
Always turn it on.

590
00:30:13.490 --> 00:30:15.760
Love that button, and it will love you.

591
00:30:15.760 --> 00:30:19.905
>> Now I understand why in the world these
funky backwards ps have been showing up.

592
00:30:19.905 --> 00:30:21.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> I used to get calls

593
00:30:21.950 --> 00:30:22.760
about this all the time.

594
00:30:22.760 --> 00:30:24.720
Why is this weird backwards p showing up?

595
00:30:24.720 --> 00:30:25.950
They were turning this on.

596
00:30:25.950 --> 00:30:27.240
So and now we know.

597
00:30:27.240 --> 00:30:28.599
It's actually a useful function, and

598
00:30:28.599 --> 00:30:30.959
not just there to irritate people
that don't know what it is [LAUGH].

599
00:30:30.959 --> 00:30:32.655
>> Yes, exactly [LAUGH].

600
00:30:32.655 --> 00:30:34.190
>> Very cool stuff, though, Vonne.

601
00:30:34.190 --> 00:30:37.600
You did a great job of showing us why
the characters that we use are there,

602
00:30:37.600 --> 00:30:42.630
how they're displayed, how characters that
aren't displayed are actually still there,

603
00:30:42.630 --> 00:30:44.720
and why they are there and
where they come from.

604
00:30:44.720 --> 00:30:46.010
And a little bit of back story,

605
00:30:46.010 --> 00:30:48.470
which was a lot of fun to go
down memory lane as well.

606
00:30:48.470 --> 00:30:49.442
We do thank you for that.

607
00:30:49.442 --> 00:30:52.050
But Vonne, it looks like we
are out of time for this episode.

608
00:30:52.050 --> 00:30:53.740
We do thank you all for watching as well.

609
00:30:53.740 --> 00:30:56.760
Signing off for Office Pro TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

610
00:30:56.760 --> 00:30:57.420
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

611
00:30:57.420 --> 00:30:59.088
>> And we'll see you next time.

612
00:30:59.088 --> 00:31:04.099
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at our well-intentioned friend known as AutoCorrect found in Word 2016. Watch as they show you AutoCorrect features like automatic formatting of lists, bullets, URLs, ordinals and fractions. They also demonstrate how Word fixes capitalization, common spelling mistakes, and a variety of other items.
episodes.title: AutoCorrect Options

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.965
[MUSIC]

00:05:14.843 --> 00:05:17.180

00:05:17.180 --> 00:05:18.822
>> No, that works, yeah.

00:05:18.822 --> 00:05:20.588

00:05:20.588 --> 00:05:23.085

00:05:23.085 --> 00:05:24.979
>> Yeah, I do remember that one, yeah.

00:05:35.558 --> 00:05:37.310

take a bunch of languages and

00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:38.034

00:05:40.333 --> 00:05:42.328

So if I wanted to type in receive R-E-C-

Okay, so H-T-E, hit the spacebar,

n some of those things, but-

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne introduce you to the revered options of cut, copy, and paste in Word 2016. They will explain the difference between cut and copy, cut/copy from within the same document, copying from websites, and copying from PDFs and other file types. They will also discuss the different paste options for matching source, matching destination, and other options that arise from specific content.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne dive into the different elements of keep options (pagination options), breaks and columns. Vonne demonstrates the different pagination options in the format paragraph dialog box such as widow and orphan control, keep lines together, and keep with next. She also describes the importance of section and page breaks to control page layout options. Lastly, they explore formatting pages/sections in columns and column breaks.
episodes.title: Keep Options, Breaks and Columns

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne dive into working with margins. Vonne shows how to control margins using preset options, individual adjustments in the dialog box, and the ruler.
